chapter.heading: Saving
chapter.text: The line-breaking algorithm in Xom is rather poor: it takes the maximum line length specified, subtracts 10, and then looks for a possible line break after that point. This makes for erratic justification, trailing space characters, and other artifacts. This is due to Xom's Serializer handles its output one character at a time and has no look ahead / read back capability.
It may be better for us to write the output file to a StringWriter or ByteArrayOutputStream and then do the breaks manually by doing ' ' to '\n' replacements.

For what it's worth, though, it's getting closer to the point where not using Xom and just doing the really minimal XML work ourselves would be feasible. Not really that interested going down the not-invented-here road, but...
chapter.heading: User interface
chapter.text: While loading, display, rendering, and saving of documents with <note> and <cite> tags is implemented, there's no user interface for adding or creating these markers yet, nor editing the reference bodies.
chapter.heading: Build
chapter.text: Top level configure is just a quick hack; probably need to copy in equivalence from java-gnome or Slashtime, though this application is potentially an opportunity to try something new.
